name: Dungeons & Dragons Online®
description: Enter a world of danger and adventure with Dungeons & Dragons Online® based on the beloved RPG that started it all.
minimum_requirements: OS:Windows® System XP SP2 Processor:P4 1.6 GHz or AMD equivalent with SSE  Memory:1 GB RAM Graphics:64 MB Hardware T&L -compatible video card  DirectX®:9.0c Hard Drive:11 GB HD space Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection Additional:*Note: Due to potential game changes, the Minimum System Requirements for this game may change over time.
recommended_requirements: OS:Windows® System Vista64/Windows 7 Processor:Dual-core processor, such as the Intel Pentium D or AMD Athlon 64 X2  Memory:2 GB RAM Graphics:256 MB NVIDIA® GeForce® 8600 or ATI Radeon™ HD 2600 or better  DirectX®:10 Hard Drive:15 GB HD space Other Requirements:Broadband Internet connection

reviews.review_text: Sadly this was ONCE a good game I would have been happy to support financially. However, it has started using questionable practices as a business. For a while I decided to simply not purchase anything in game and hoped that those in charge would get the message as fewer people used their software. However, recently, an update installed that broke the camel's back. Software known as Akamai netcient or some such tried to force install itself onto my computer when I tried to use the client. It was caught by my compter's security thankfully and was blocked. Upon looking further it sends bandwidth and your computer data in a peer to peer network. This is HIGHLY questionable and furthermore a major breach to your computer's security. They have recently stopped using Akamai netclient though I still do not like how they choose to gouge customers for money since they literally cannot find any quests after about level 10 since they require you to buy access to the content. However, if you go for a subscription then it is likely a fun game, though only if you wish to use a subscription plan and get access to all the features and zones.  Just checked it again. Turns out they went back to using Akamei. If you value your computer's security, AVOID TURBINE LIKE THE PLAGUE!!!
Do not buy any of the adventure packs direct through steam  it is not reasonable to do so  buy direct in game or VIP only :S  unless you have infinite money or no smarts

I started to play this game in 2009 at that time it was Dungeons and Dragons Eberron Unlimited. I played it quiet a long time approximately 1000+ hours. We started with bunch of friends for fun but then all of a sudden it became serious we were addicted this game was amazing, we cleared lots of dungeons had the best items, paid for some expansions. After a long time i started to play it again and with a fresh ideas. My review is short and simple as always.    PROs: -Gameplay is amazing. -Dungeons are really detailed and great. -Leveling system and classes are different than usual but its better in most ways.  -Quests are good and not boring. -You can create really good Builds with a fantastic skill tree system -It's a game to play with a group friends. (for me the solo is a little boring) not just for fun because in lots of dungeons you need different classes and roles to have the most of it.   CONs -The graphic are getting old and decent for our time. -There is a lot of, i mean A LOT OF, 'paid' content like expansions, character slots, classes, races... goes on.  -It's not a free world there is only cities , towns to roam, shop etc. and dungeons (instances) for some action. -Not too much players: Population is really low. -The game is dying and perhaps nearly dead.  It's a wholla lotta different gamplay experience. I recommend this game. I love this game. it has a different place for me. I suggest you to play it (if possible play it with some friends), experience it, than its all your decision to like it or not.   Have Fun!
Everything changed when the money nation attacked...
It's ok I guess...

A fantastic take on DDO based in Eberron lore, They recently tied it in with the Forgotten Realms with the Underdark Adventure Pack. Very in depth character creation stats wise. Not very many options to customize your toons look though. All bodies are the same pretty much. Definitely some of the best dungeon crawls and seasonal events. not much in the way of pvp though. Highly recommended.

No other MMORPG like it.... I love everything, but especially how dungeons are these deep, dark places with tons of different monsters, UNIQUE quests, class customization is insanely versatile, and combat is engaging and intelligent! The only con is the player base is pretty low, so groups are hard to find. Other wise I would highly reccomend this game.

I've been playing this game for over 6 years and it is still by far my favorite mmo. The graphics are a bit I outdated it is still very good considering its age. I love how many classes they have and all their enhancement trees is amazing.
Always more fun when you bring a friend to watch your back

I enjoyed this game for 4 years. I loved its combat system, instanced dungeons and social focus.  However, the game has taken a turn for the worst.  tl;dr Money is basically irrelevant unless you have a lot of it. Difficulty is meaningless. Either you can solo elite or your build isn't viable. Difficulty takes the form of giving the mobs more stats instead of actual meaningful difficulty.   Pros: - Fun for groups. - Innovative true reincarnation system. - Multiclassing and build planning is fun. - Still updating.  Neutral: - Grindy but not bad. If you know how to do the dungeon, it takes 3-10 minutes to complete it and you normally do it 3/5 times minimum, 10 times maximum. - True reincarnation adds to the grind.  Cons: - Might as well be a subscription game. You hit a brick wall at level 14 unless you're spending money. Or grinding for favor. - Very strict definition of what is viable, especially in the newer dungeons and at high level. - It's a dying game. Hard to find groups if you're not at the high levels. - Not recommended unless you have a premade group that plays regularly. - Regularly bugged. Not too intrusive, but not recommended if you don't have patience. - Updates aren't fixing the problem.
Great fun and great character customization as far as the skills/abilities/spells go

Overall, I give this game a thumbs up. The game has been around a while and has an established community. There is plenty of content. As a dungeons and dragons game, it has several races and classes to choose from and at each level you can choose class and skills, similar to the 3rd edition(s) of dungeons and dragons. I found the gameplay smooth and controls easy to use. Quests were entertaining and I liked exlporing the city. The quests are all instanced so you don't have to compete, though you can take a party of adventurers. When my friends weren't available, I found content that I could manage by myself or with one of the game's hirelings (AI helper). There is some content that you don't get with the free to play - extra races, some dungeon areas, and a few classes - but there is still plenty of content to keep you interested all the way to highest levels. I do note that PVP was very limited - only in special arenas in the taverns (bar fights). Graphics are excellent. As expected in D&D, there are tons of spells, equipment, monster types, etc. Stealth and lockpicking are included and work well.
A very fun mmo

Good game if you like DND , very close to what I would think an adventure looks like if you could have a movie of it in your head. Good number of quest and different items to make each player different.   Downside, running missions over and over to get faction and rewards.
I personally love it... Good ole' classic. However, playing this by yourself is not the greatest... Playing with friends is relatively fun however, I could play it for hours with friends.
love playing this game!!!!!!!!!!!!!
I really don't even know where to start saying why i dislike this game... but i'll play it for one reason... family.

DD is literally the best game i have played. From the action combat to the traps in dungeons its awesome. Another plus is that almost any pc can run it decently. Theres quite a few classes (16 if i remember right) that you can chose from which fall into 4 main categories. you have stealth range warrior and mage essentially. It is however very instanced but the load time isnt to bad even for low spec pcs. Each weapon is strong agenst specific enemys such as blades being ineffective agenst skeletons but maces are and vice versa for undead. If your looking for a game thats fun to quest grind and etc in this is the game for you. It gets even more fun when you get a whole guild in an area. It makes you feel very powerfull. There are plenty of toutorials to help you through the game so i would highly suggest at least trying it. If its not for you then whatever you just had a bit of fun and passed some time!

Okay, so I'll be the first to admit that this is not the MMO for everyone. It is rather dated, has a few issues once in a while, and lacks some of the quality of life features of some newer MMO's. However, it is a character builder's dream, with the ability to endlessly tinker with various builds and classes and the freedom to build your character however you want, with stats, skills, and feats freely allocated allowing for clever and unique builds for those who want to try something new and impressive optimization for power gamers. The community is by and large decent, and while there are probably a few bad apples, I haven't had any terrible experiences. The game is both solo and party friendly, and the more recalcitrant solo players can bring along hirelings, AI companions, to help out if the going gets tough. Dungeons can be run on four difficulties, a pansy mode for cowardly weaklings, a normal mode for weaklings, a hard mode for regular players, and expert for power builds! (Okay, I generalized there.) There is a lot of content for free, and subscribing unlocks access to most of the content for a monthly fee. Otherwise, you can buy or earn turbine points to get content packs to expand your experience. The cash shop is prevalent and offers advantages, but free to play is sufficient to get a good start in the game and there's not really a crippling disadvantage to free players that would force them to pay.

Very enjoyable game ^^ Love the playstyle and balancing of the game. Very tough and focused on proper play and teamwork within a small group of people. Plenty of fun classes with diverse playstyles.  Easily top 3 game I've ever played. Comes back to me in the form of flashbacks, regularly.

I got blown the ♥♥♥♥ up on the detonated ship quest because I was oblivious to the timed explosives my party had placed on the ship I was calmly checking out. Then I turn and see my party standing on the shore, spamming messages like 'run!' 'get off the ship noob' and 'he wont make it'. That's when the ship exploded and cracked in half, and my body was sent up in the sky and stayed there, too high for any party members to possibly revive me

I don't understand how (since the unfortunate and untimely demise of SWG), anyone can play any other MMORPG. I mean, in all fairness, other titles might have the advantage of being a venerable title (WOW), or have a massive fan following (either FF XI/XIV), but when it all comes down to style, playability, and taking full advantage of the MMO perks, by incorporating them into the games construction, DDO, has done exactly what it set out to do...Emulate the adventures of the pen & paper game that has reached critical acclaim from loyal fans the world over.  All the versatility of the tabletop format is right here at your fingertips. You want to customize your stats and feats to build the most critical to form shield & sword knight, emphasizing value of honor and virtue, or become a shadow walker with deft fingers and mythic ability? You can. In fact, you can be both at the same time!  Multiclass? Yes, please! I found myself easily bored by other MMO's and their linearal ability trees; maxing out my characters to get a taste of their potential, only to wish that there was more I was capable of doing.  WOW? Pffft... not if the game paid me! DDO is the closest experience to the tabletop format as you can possibly get, without actually drawing up a world yourself.  And trust me, if you enjoy this game for even a minute, do yourself a favour, go pick up some dice. When you experience all that D&D can be, you'll never turn your back. It's the ultimate high.

There's always adventure around every corner with players looking to accomplish the quest goals. Or perhaps you'll like to belong to a pack & reap the benifits of a virtual friendship or family like relations within this rpg. Most importantly you'll always be learning your character's class and math that goes into survivial growth of your journey.   It's a wonderful break away from the usual sole dueling games provided on here..However you can always duel any players you wish in this world and create you own reputation on how you interacte with anyone! Don't forget to visit their store to enjoy all the De-lightful gear and comestic products to make you look attractive and smart.

For an MMO this was pretty good. I had a lot of fun playing this and had I invested money into the game, I probably would have played longer too. I liked the idea of the Guilds and the ship too. But I have a short attention span and get bored doing mindless hash and slash after a while and am essentially done playing MMOs for good.  If you like mid-evil MMO's than this is definitely a fun one to check out. It has a decent story and unlike most other MMO's allows some customization with your leveling up.  But if you aren't a fan of MMO's such as myself, then don't expect anything spectacular here that will change your mind on those types of games.
love it you can do alomost anything

I would definately recommend this game for anyone that is a fan of the D&D table top games. A perfect game to get the old group back together from where ever they are for a few hours once or twice a week for some old time fun.

Grab some friends and play together through the free content at least. The cash shop is kind of unique. In that you can buy perminant content that would otherwise require you to keep paying a sub to have access to. The game itself is fun for a while. Tho after level 8 or 9 the game is a bit repeatative and grindy. Tho you will surely have fun until then. Best recommendation is to play with people you know. Makes it tons funner that way.

This translates the game into a video game well enough. If you came to this for an exact clone of the game then you will be, perhaps, disapointed. But overall it is a fun game that gets the spirit of D&D quite nicely. Though there isn't a wide selection of races/classes you can customise your character very well, effectivly making it unique. The gameplay is fun as it translates what the experiance of combat would actually be like. A great game.

Also, it is sooooo restricted by whether you spend money on it, to the point where I wanted to play as a drow wizard, but no, I had to pay money for that. I didn't like it either, as it took for ever to get to the 2nd town, ( I perservered ) hoping against hope that there would be no more grinding to do, but guess what, there was! This game is free, and still I haven't gotten my money's worth, playing Magicka Wizard Wars instead, strangely addicting...  ps, it says I played 22 hours of this game, that was with one character and I got to lvl 6,(Iperservered some more, then gave up) Magicka Wizard Wars and Diablo 3 are both way better, play those instead

Take the hub based world and instanced dungeons from Guild Wars and add in D&D3.5 rules and active combat and you get DDO. If you want to attack, hit the attack button. Want to block, hit the block button. You control all the actions of your character. Although the shipped version wasn't the greatest, this game has grown exponentially greater with each update. Any D&D fan or MMO fan should give it a try.
many people hated this game when it was first released. however DDO has changed quite a bit from the release date and has slowly gotten better with each new fix

This is a online version of the old boad game and i'd say is probubly better because you can play it on your own time and not have to deal with other players or taking turns, I mean yea the original is fun but I hated having to wait and if we didn't finish it in time we would have to do it the next day and having to remember everything was just a pain so if you like D&D then I would suggest this for you

Im not an MMO guy, But this is a great mmo if you want to have some fun with friends Great game

Let me start this off by saying I've played this game for far longer than my playtime says. In fact, it was one of the first PC games I ever played, and to this day it's still one of my favorites. The world is interesting, the diversity of spells and abilities you can get is astounding, and it boasts the unique (so far as I know) feature of calculating stats and damage like an actual game of tabletop D&D. You even get a couple Dungeon Masters narrating the things you do, which I always thought was a nice touch. The sixteen-odd classes, with the ability to multiclass up to three times, and various races are each fairly intriguing, though there isn't really much you can do in the way of customization. Still, you can play as a magic robot. That's pretty cool. The graphics are definitely showing their age, and I've run into my fair share of bugs, but it's never stopped me from having a good time. Still, the game is far from perfect, and there's a few pieces of advice I'd like to give to those interested in picking it up:  1. Get some friends to play with you. This game is fine on its own, but, as with tabletop D&D, a couple friends makes it far better. The playerbase for this game is fairly small, and public groups arent' as common as they once were. If you want to co-op, chances are you'll have to seek outside help.  2. Be prepared to spend money. Not on items, or gear, or things like that, but on adventure packs. This game isn't pay-to-win (how could it be, it's mostly co-op), but you do have to pay for a great deal of content. This can either be in the form of a subscription (I don't know how much that is exactly), or for adventure packs, for which you use TP, the game's freemium currency, to unlock specific quest chains. For some people, that might be an instant turn-off, but if you're like me and have trouble sticking to one game for too long, You'll probably appreciate the ability to pay as you go, rather than keep shelling out money for a game you may not be interested in at the moment. You can, as with most games, go through and unlock all of the areas for free eventually, but not unless you're willing to endure a rather long grind. I'm talking like multiple characters on multiple servers long. If you're not quite sure if you're willing to spend money on a free-to-play game, there's still enough free stuff to get a feel for if you like the game, and you can still have plenty of fun without spending a cent.  Also, not sure if this is on my end or something with the game, but I've found the controls to be a tad slow and unresponsive as of late. Again, not sure if this is the game, or my computer, I've had similar problems in a few other games. To conclude, not a bad game, if you like D&D you'll probably like this. Really I'm just writing this in the hopes of keeping it alive.

I sank a lot more in to this game pre-Steam. DDO remains the best online MMO experience using the D&D 3rd edition ruleset, and is really a great experience, despite the fact that it show it's age. However....after it went F2P it developed increasingly elaborate monetary systems, weird crafting rules and lots of freemiu options that often felt necessary but weere very costly unless a sale was on. If you prefer soloing or can't find players....a real problem at times....then you need to spend money on henchmen, too; the game is more balanced now than ever for solo play compared to when it started, but forget trying to go it alone without a healer, for example.   DDO is not perfect, and it's aged badly, and I dislike the cash shop's excessive prices (I never bought something if it wasn't on sale as a rule) but it's still an innovative MMORPG and the best such type of game D&D has ever been translated in to.
It would be great... IF IT DIDN'T COST £15 FOR A DAMN CLASS.

Treat the cash shop like the books that must be acquired during a standard D&D paper game; content is only to enhance the player's chances. The 'must purchases,' conveniently, are given on the Store Page.

Dungeons and dragons online is an abomination. I thought WoW was bad, but holy ♥♥♥♥! First off, Subscription, it's optional, without it you get a fairly decent game, filled with things you can't do because you won't give them money. So why buy a subscription? You get to waste your savings getting fictional currency, an exp boost and one or two classes which are free after some months of subscription, 99 dollars per year. Turbine Points! The exciting piece, to get 23k Turbine points, it costs 200 dollars!(199.99) About 128 pounds according to Google. Rediculous, as The Druid class costs 1.3k turbine points, and to play as a half orc costs about the same, About 7 other classes and 3 other races also cost the same. You can only make 4 characters, or pay 600 points for another slot, this can be done 30 times. The store is rediculous, blizzard are expensive in selling mounts for real money, but they don't come any where near the quantity of stuff these guys are smoking *Cough* Selling. 200-500 points For companions, which do nothing except follow you, Just like in WoW, but these cost money. You can only change their name once, or have to pay money to do so again. Finally, it's very pay to win(Or Lose at life), you can buy experience and stat points to improve your character, becoming immensely overpowered, the more money you put into it. You can also buy the in game currency, in a much more direct way than you can on WoW nowadays. This game is terrible, I don't recommend it, the graphics aren't anything special, especially considering it's only 9 years old and WoW is 10. I'd suggest playing Runescape instead, the graphics are prettier, it has nicer music and it's a lot cheaper for it's micro transactions.
Not a terrible game.  But there are better MMOs out there that don't seem so reliant on throwing your money at it.

If you've played any of the Baldur's Gate or the first two Neverwinter Nights games (or, heck, even table-top DnD games) you already know this game sucks. That being said, I can also add that the graphics are sub-par and the game mechanics are pretty weak. Its only redeeming quality is that it's free (well, as a 'free' as MOST free-to-play games are...which means, 'if you want a decent game experience, you're probably going to have to pay something'). I guess it's worth downloading, if you have the disk space, just to screw around with for a few hours...but, overall, it's not a very good game.

Ive been playing this game for about awhile, just found it on steam. Played with my father in 2007, then started playing again last year and nostalgia hit me. Its an amazing game, harder to learn than any other mmo ive played, but its very worth it. Im not very experienced im just a huge fan and would like to gain experience, so if any experienced players see this, feel free to hit up any of my characters and quest with me and help me out along the road. I play on Khyber Server and my Characters i play on are -Ashyoni, Hashslinging, Joseran, Mureyia, and Galladio. But anyway back to the review. DDO is a fantastic game, very worth the time invested to learn and level and reincarnate and do it all again. Find some people in ur level range and just quest till ur fingers fall off. You wont regret it.

I'm not an expert when it comes to D&D mechanics. I can't say much about it. I'm just someone who is looking for some MMORPG game and when it comes to Dungeons & Dragons Online, it failed. Maybe because I expected a little bit less of action in this kind of game. Not sure how popular it is but I haven't managed to find anybody to play with together. Even if there are only 'pros' left, it's a hard to get into DDO world alone. Still, it's a free to play game, it's just my reaction and what I think about this game. It didn't appeal to me, so check it out yourself.

I frequently confuse this game and neverwinter, Being as this one is from Turbine i can tell you right now bring your wallet. But in saying that it will be a great game.

There are a lot of Dungeons and Dragons games for both console and pc but this one will always hold a special place in my heart. I will start off by saying that the way combat is handled in this game leaves a little something to be desired as most people I know find it to be a little clunky. But that is only if you look at it as a standard MMO game.  When you change the perspective and look at this game as being Dungeons and Dragons you look past that one little flaw. This game has the most detailed create a character giving you the most accurate feel to creating a character for the live table top game. With everything from ability scores, to skill points, feats, and spells there is literally no end to the different ways you can build a character.  I myself constantly find that I am deleting characters to try out new ideas and crazy builds. With multiclassing and well thought out enhancement trees this game takes Dungeons and Dragons to a whole new level!

I Love this MMO, since when I go on adventure with my friends, I dont have to se spawning enemys behind my back or other players running past me and kill my Boss. One Sad thing was when they put in flying ships, as a guild thing. Why could we not just get an odenaryship, no we have to sky high with flying ships the Gary Gygax way. So I stop play this really good D&D game that follows the rule set.
Really fun game! Love the combat, atmosphere, Dungeon Master... very enjoyable and unique!

play it! best game IN the world

I LOVE this game. I'm a dedicated D&D tabletop player. I've been playing Pathfinder since it's inception. I know how it all works. I love that this takes D&D to a new level. You can actually play without friends because you can find others online to play with you with the LFG feature OR play with friends and have a blast solving puzzles and slicing enemies.  My recommendation to people new to the game like I was, but familiar with D&D: do NOT follow the pre-built path. Build your own. It will help you so much in the long run as the computer generated paths tend to put your points in the wrong things.   Make your own mistakes rather than letting a computer do it for you. This game is amazing, I would highly recommend paying for some of the features. The subscription is no worse than subscribing for any other MMO.
its good
It is a fine game, but it can never ever beat the original version of D&D, with pen, paper, tons of dice and a group of friends.

Best! MMO! Ever!  upside:  - Every Quest has something unique. No boring 'Get 10 items' - Every Quest is an Instance. No waiting in line for a mob respawn. - Every Instance has 4 to 5 different difficult settings. From Solo to EPIC. In hard mode and above you cant regenerate health and mana. A fail means you have to start the whole quest again. So every moment is exiting. - This game uses ALOT of the original Paper and Pen rules (with some exceptions). - Complex crafting system. - Demonweb Pits as a raid instance!!!  downside:  - 'Free to play'...uh not really. Quests do cost money if you want to do them after a certain level. But if you like it, I recommend going for the subscription. - When you like to play on hard (like me) you will have problems without a rogue in your group. The traps REALLY hurt. I wiped alot stepping in traps. - graphics a re a bit out of date. But on the upper side it has some really creative things. Just have a look at the Phiarlan Area at night. Beautiful

I would have recommended this game wholeheartedly when I first played it. Four years ago. I loved it. Now, it has frequent bouts of unplayable lag and it seems like they're not going to fix it anytime soon. If you can handle being frozen for 2 minutes at a time and possibly dying every 20 minutes go for it. This game is one of my favorites and I'm sad I can't play it anymore.
Not bad for a MMORPG I personally like it better than WOW.
I never seen the great game like this,pretty story and setting. I played this game for three years,really like !
If you like smashing boxes, opening big chests, slaying big dragons and DnD in general, this game is for you!

This is the MMORPG that started it all! I used to play this all of the time, and now that it has come to steam I expect it to be even better! A great Fantasy MMORPG with a D&D style combat system based on an involuntary dice system for damage that you never really notice. It has a good amount of dungeons, a fun teamwork styled gameplay, and challenging bosses!
